content: Yes, the president of Mexico has some additional powers when it comes to enforcing laws compared to the Chamber of Deputies. For example, the president has the power to issue executive orders, which can be used to enforce existing laws and regulations or to establish new policies. The president also has the power to appoint officials responsible for ensuring that laws are enforced, such as judges and law enforcement officers. Additionally, the president can call for the deployment of the military to assist in the enforcement of certain laws, particularly in cases of national security or emergency. However, it is important to note that the president must still work in conjunction with the Chamber of Deputies to ensure that laws are properly implemented and that the balance of power between the branches of government is upheld.
